content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a rational human player, I would consider the expected value of each choice. In this game, if I choose R and my opponent chooses B, I lose 5$ per round. If they choose R and I choose B, they lose 5$ per round. However, if we both pick the same option, I gain 5$ per round (45$ in the case of R and 40$ in the case of B).

Since the game has 75 rounds, a loss of 5$ per round for one choice would amount to a total loss of 375$, while the same choice would result in a total gain of 375$. On the other hand, the gain from choosing the opposite option and having the opponent choose the same would be a total gain of 1875$, while the loss for the opponent choosing the opposite option and me choosing the same would be a total loss of 1125$.

Given that the opponent's choice is anonymous, it is reasonable to assume that they are also rational. In this case, since they have an incentive to maximize their earnings, we can expect them to choose R more often than B. This makes the payout for choosing R lower and the payout for choosing B higher.

Taking all factors into account, I would choose B, as it offers a higher expected value (1875$ - 1125$ = 750$) compared to choosing R (375$ - (-375$) = 750$). Thus, my choice is B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Given that my opponent chose R in the previous round, I will choose B in the next round, hoping that they will switch their choice to R and giving me a higher payout of 40$. However, if they stick with their choice of R again, I will still earn 35$, which is better than the 0$ I would receive if I had chosen R. Thus, my choice for the next round is B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
